bill.constitutionalAuthorityStatementText: [Congressional Record Volume 167, Number 75 (Friday, April 30, 2021)][House]From the Congressional Record Online through the Government Publishing Office [www.gpo.gov]By Mrs. MURPHY of Florida:H.R. 2933.Congress has the power to enact this legislation pursuantto the following:Article I, Section 8, Clause 18, ``To make all Laws whichshall be necessary and proper for carrying into the Executionthe foregoing Powers, and all other Powers vested by thisConstitution in the Government of the United States, or inany Department of Officer thereof.''[Page H2135]

item.title: Securing a Strong Retirement Act of 2021

latestAction.text: Received in the Senate and Read twice and referred to the Committee on Finance.

item.text: Referred to the House Committee on Ways and Means.

summary.text: This bill increases the age (currently, age 72) at which taxpayers are required to make minimum distributions from tax-exempt retirement plans. For taxpayers who attain age 72 after December 31, 2026, the age is increased to 73; for taxpayers who attain age 73 after December 31, 2032, the age is increased to 75.

bill.title: To amend the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to increase the age for the beginning date for required minimum distributions.

item.title: To amend the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to increase the age for the beginning date for required minimum distributions.
To amend the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to increase the age for the beginning date for required minimum distributions.

latestAction.text: Referred to the House Committee on Ways and Means.

dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.
dublinCore.dc:contributor: Congressional Research Service, Library of Congress
dublinCore.dc:description: This file contains bill summaries and statuses for federal legislation. A bill summary describes the most significant provisions of a piece of legislation and details the effects the legislative text may have on current law and federal programs. Bill summaries are authored by the Congressional Research Service (CRS) of the Library of Congress. As stated in Public Law 91-510 (2 USC 166 (d)(6)), one of the duties of CRS is "to prepare summaries and digests of bills and resolutions of a public general nature introduced in the Senate or House of Representatives". For more information, refer to the User Guide that accompanies this file.
